message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of an open fracture and worsening pain in the arm, suggesting the possibility of acute compartment syndrome. Physical exam findings of severe pain with passive motion and tenderness to palpation also support this diagnosis. The next best step in management is an emergency fasciotomy to relieve the pressure in the compartment and prevent further tissue damage. Ibuprofen and reassurance may not address the underlying issue and radiography may not be helpful in diagnosing compartment syndrome. Measurement of compartment pressure may be useful, but the patient's severe symptoms warrant more urgent intervention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest compartment syndrome, which is a surgical emergency. Radiography may be helpful to evaluate for any new fracture or dislocation, but it won't help diagnose compartment syndrome. Measurement of compartment pressure is necessary to confirm the diagnosis, but emergency fasciotomy is the recommended treatment for compartment syndrome. Therefore, emergency fasciotomy is the next best step in management for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The worsening pain and tenderness to palpation in a patient with a recent fracture suggests the possibility of compartment syndrome. Measurement of compartment pressure can confirm the diagnosis, but emergency fasciotomy is the definitive treatment and should be performed as soon as possible to prevent irreversible muscle and nerve damage. Radiography may be helpful to rule out new fractures, but it is not urgent in this situation. Ibuprofen and reassurance alone is not appropriate for a suspected compartment syndrome.
